name: command_of_the_message
description: A framework focused on controlling the buyer's journey through quantified business impact and value realization

components.name: Situation
components.description: Understanding of customer's current business context and operational environment

subComponents.name: Current State Assessment
subComponents.description: How well the customer's existing situation, processes, and challenges are understood

scoringCriteria.excellent: Comprehensive understanding of current state with detailed process documentation and system mapping
scoringCriteria.good: Good grasp of current situation with clear understanding of key processes and systems
scoringCriteria.fair: Basic understanding of current state but lacks detail in key areas
scoringCriteria.poor: Limited or superficial understanding of customer's current situation

coachingTips: Map current processes step-by-step before discussing problems
Document existing systems and technology investments
Understand organizational structure and decision-making process

subComponents.name: Business Context
subComponents.description: Understanding of broader business environment, priorities, and strategic initiatives

scoringCriteria.excellent: Clear understanding of business strategy, priorities, and how this initiative fits into broader objectives
scoringCriteria.good: Good grasp of business context and strategic alignment
scoringCriteria.fair: Some understanding of business context but lacks strategic perspective
scoringCriteria.poor: Limited understanding of broader business environment and priorities

coachingTips: Connect to quarterly and annual business objectives
Understand competitive pressures and market dynamics
Map to organizational initiatives and strategic priorities

components.name: Problem
components.description: Clear articulation and quantification of specific problems preventing desired outcomes

subComponents.name: Problem Definition
subComponents.description: How clearly specific, measurable problems are identified and articulated

scoringCriteria.excellent: Problems are clearly defined, specific, and measurable with detailed business impact
scoringCriteria.good: Problems are well-articulated with clear business relevance
scoringCriteria.fair: Problems are identified but lack specificity or clear measurement
scoringCriteria.poor: Problems are vague, generic, or not clearly defined

coachingTips: Ask for specific examples and situations
Quantify problems in business terms (time, cost, impact)
Avoid accepting surface-level problem descriptions

subComponents.name: Problem Quantification
subComponents.description: How well problems are quantified in terms of business impact, cost, and measurable consequences

scoringCriteria.excellent: Problems are thoroughly quantified with specific business impact metrics and financial implications
scoringCriteria.good: Good quantification of problems with clear business impact measurement
scoringCriteria.fair: Some quantification provided but lacks depth or specificity
scoringCriteria.poor: Problems are not quantified or only vague impact statements provided

coachingTips: Always ask 'How much?' and 'How many?' when discussing problems
Calculate both direct and indirect costs
Include time impact, resource waste, and opportunity costs

subComponents.name: Root Cause Analysis
subComponents.description: Understanding of why problems exist and what underlying factors contribute to them

scoringCriteria.excellent: Clear understanding of root causes with analysis of underlying factors and systemic issues
scoringCriteria.good: Good grasp of why problems exist with reasonable causal analysis
scoringCriteria.fair: Some understanding of causes but lacks depth or systemic perspective
scoringCriteria.poor: Limited understanding of root causes or only surface-level analysis

coachingTips: Use '5 Why' technique to get to root causes
Distinguish between symptoms and underlying causes
Look for systemic issues rather than just isolated problems

components.name: Solution
components.description: Positioning of solution as direct response to identified problems and situation

subComponents.name: Solution Positioning
subComponents.description: How well solution capabilities are mapped to identified problems and customer needs

scoringCriteria.excellent: Solution capabilities are directly and specifically mapped to identified problems with clear connection
scoringCriteria.good: Good alignment between solution and problems with clear positioning
scoringCriteria.fair: Some connection made but could be more specific or compelling
scoringCriteria.poor: Weak connection between solution and identified problems

coachingTips: Map each solution capability to specific identified problems
Use customer language when describing solution benefits
Focus on business outcomes rather than technical features

subComponents.name: Differentiation
subComponents.description: How well solution is differentiated from alternatives and competitive options

scoringCriteria.excellent: Clear differentiation with specific advantages and unique value propositions versus alternatives
scoringCriteria.good: Good differentiation with reasonable competitive positioning
scoringCriteria.fair: Some differentiation mentioned but lacks specificity or compelling advantage
scoringCriteria.poor: Weak or generic differentiation without clear competitive advantage

coachingTips: Address specific customer concerns about alternatives
Highlight unique capabilities that competitors can't match
Use customer criteria to frame competitive advantages

components.name: Value
components.description: Quantified business value and return on investment of implementing the solution

subComponents.name: Quantified Benefits
subComponents.description: How well business benefits are quantified with specific ROI and business impact

scoringCriteria.excellent: Benefits are thoroughly quantified with specific ROI calculations and measurable business impact
scoringCriteria.good: Good quantification of benefits with clear business value proposition
scoringCriteria.fair: Some benefit quantification but lacks detail or compelling ROI
scoringCriteria.poor: Benefits are generic or not quantified with weak value proposition

coachingTips: Base ROI calculations on customer-specific problem quantification
Include both hard benefits (cost savings) and soft benefits
Show multiple value scenarios (conservative, expected, optimistic)

subComponents.name: Value Realization Timeline
subComponents.description: Clear timeline for when benefits will be realized and value achieved

scoringCriteria.excellent: Clear value realization timeline with specific milestones and phased benefit delivery
scoringCriteria.good: Good timeline for value realization with reasonable milestone definition
scoringCriteria.fair: Some timeline provided but lacks specificity or milestone clarity
scoringCriteria.poor: Vague or no timeline for value realization

coachingTips: Break value realization into phases and milestones
Connect timeline to customer's business calendar
Show early wins and long-term value progression

components.name: Measurement
components.description: Clear metrics and framework for measuring success and value realization

subComponents.name: Success Metrics Definition
subComponents.description: How clearly success metrics and measurement criteria are defined

scoringCriteria.excellent: Success metrics are clearly defined, measurable, and aligned with business objectives
scoringCriteria.good: Good metric definition with clear measurement approach
scoringCriteria.fair: Some metrics defined but lack clarity or business alignment
scoringCriteria.poor: Metrics are vague or not clearly defined

coachingTips: Define both leading and lagging indicators
Align metrics with customer's existing measurement practices
Establish baseline measurements for comparison

subComponents.name: Measurement Timeline
subComponents.description: Clear schedule and process for measuring and reviewing progress

scoringCriteria.excellent: Clear measurement timeline with specific review periods and accountability framework
scoringCriteria.good: Good measurement schedule with reasonable review process
scoringCriteria.fair: Some measurement timeline but lacks specificity or regular review process
scoringCriteria.poor: No clear measurement timeline or review process

coachingTips: Establish regular review and reporting schedule
Define who is responsible for tracking and reporting
Create accountability framework for measurement

components.name: Value Realization Event
components.description: Understanding of timeline and critical business events that drive urgency

subComponents.name: Timeline Definition
subComponents.description: How clearly critical dates and deadlines are defined and understood

scoringCriteria.excellent: Critical dates clearly defined with specific business reasoning and urgency factors
scoringCriteria.good: Timeline is reasonably clear with business context and deadlines
scoringCriteria.fair: Some timeline mentioned but lacks specificity or business justification
scoringCriteria.poor: Timeline is vague, flexible, or not clearly defined

coachingTips: Connect timeline to customer's business calendar and critical events
Identify external pressures (regulatory, competitive, seasonal)
Calculate cost of delay in implementing solution

subComponents.name: Value Realization Understanding
subComponents.description: Understanding of why timing is critical and what drives the urgency for value realization

scoringCriteria.excellent: Clear understanding of why timing is critical with specific business drivers and value realization factors
scoringCriteria.good: Good understanding of timing importance with reasonable business justification
scoringCriteria.fair: Some understanding of timing but lacks clarity on urgency drivers
scoringCriteria.poor: Limited understanding of why timing matters or weak urgency justification

coachingTips: Understand budget cycles and fiscal year planning
Identify competitive pressures and market timing factors
Connect to organizational changes and strategic initiatives
